channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Majority of Minneapolis City Council Pledges to Dismantle Police Department
item.description: Some cities are starting to to heed calls to “defund the police,” as lawmakers push proposals for greater police accountability. National Guard troops are being sent home from Washington, D.C.
item.media:credit: Laylah Amatullah Barrayn for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters in Powderhorn Park in Minneapolis on Sunday called for the defunding of the city’s Police Department.

item.title: George Floyd Protests Add New Front Line for Coronavirus Doctors
item.description: Many physicians wish to show solidarity at the demonstrations, but some fear a second wave of infection will follow.
item.dc:creator: Emma Goldberg
item.media:credit: Yuki Iwamura/Associated Press
item.media:description: Mount Sinai nurses and doctors cheered on protesters at Union Square in Manhattan on Tuesday.

item.title: Coronavirus Jumps the Border, Overwhelming Hospitals in California
item.description: Hospitals are airlifting patients to facilities hundreds of miles away to handle an influx of Americans and U.S. green card holders sickened in Mexico.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan
item.media:credit: Ariana Drehsler/Reuters
item.media:description: A healthcare worker in protective gear treats a patient with the coronavirus at the El Centro Regional Medical Center in El Centro, Calif., last week.

item.title: Despite Recession, Stock Markets Turn Positive for the Year
item.description: The S&P 500 climbed back above where it began the year on the same day that economists said the United States fell into a recession in February.
item.dc:creator: Matt Phillips

item.title: CrossFit Gyms Meets Black Lives Matter
item.description: CrossFit inspires extreme devotion. Now it’s repelling sponsors, gym affiliates and alienating its community.
item.dc:creator: Katherine Rosman and Lauren Hard

item.title: The Travel Business is Picking Up for Summer
item.description: After months of staying at home during the pandemic, Americans are heading to vacation destinations like Florida and national parks.
item.dc:creator: Niraj Chokshi
item.media:credit: Josh Ritchie for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Fontainebleau Miami Beach, a resort that had closed because of the coronavirus pandemic, is enjoying brisk business since it reopened on June 1.

item.title: Man Who Drove Into Protesters Said He Was a K.K.K. Leader, Prosecutors Say
item.description: Harry H. Rogers drove into a group of demonstrators near Richmond, Va., on Sunday, the authorities said. The county prosecutor called him “an admitted leader of the Ku Klux Klan.”
item.dc:creator: Jacey Fortin
item.media:credit: Henrico County Police
item.media:description: It was unclear whether Harry H. Rogers’s claims about his membership in the Ku Klux Klan were true. He is currently being held without bond.

item.title: How to Feed Crowds in a Protest or Pandemic? The Sikhs Know
item.description: Their centuries-old faith tradition of nourishing anyone in need has found new energy and purpose in America’s turmoil.
item.dc:creator: Priya Krishna
item.media:credit: Ryan Christopher Jones for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Queens Village group fed people last week at a Sunnyside protest over the killing of George Floyd and other black Americans by the police.

item.title: Biden Pours Millions Into Facebook Ads, Blowing Past Trump’s Record
item.description: Joe Biden spent $1.6 million on Facebook last Thursday as his campaign capitalized on energy surrounding mass protests. That’s far more than President Trump has spent on the platform on a single day.
item.dc:creator: Shane Goldmacher
item.media:credit: Mark Makela for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Biden campaign’s biggest online advertising blitz of the 2020 race has gathered contact information from more than 1.2 million people, a valuable collection of potential donors.

item.title: Democrats Unveil Sweeping Bill Targeting Police Misconduct and Racial Bias
item.description: The measure, the most expansive intervention into policing that lawmakers have proposed in recent memory, is likely to draw opposition from Republicans and police unions.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker/The New York Times
item.media:description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi and other Democratic leaders commemorated the lives of George Floyd, Breonna Taylor and Ahmaud Arbery in the Capitol on Monday.

item.title: Boxed Lunches and Plexiglass Will Welcome Back Wall Street’s Workers
item.description: The finance industry will return to its offices this month, but the landscape is likely to be altered for many months to come.
item.dc:creator: Kate Kelly

item.title: What Would Efforts to Defund or Disband Police Departments Really Mean?
item.description: Much is not yet certain, but here’s what is known so far about some efforts to defund or abolish police departments.
item.dc:creator: Dionne Searcey
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters walk in a Defund the Police march Saturday, in Minneapolis.

item.title: Biden Walks a Cautious Line as He Opposes Defunding the Police
item.description: As gruesome videos and energetic protests reshape public opinion about racial discrimination, Joe Biden tried to balance protesters’ calls for a law enforcement overhaul while not alienating moderate voters.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Martin, Alexander Burns and Thomas Kaplan
item.media:credit: Mark Makela for The New York Times
item.media:description: Joseph R. Biden Jr., the presumptive Democratic presidential nominee, has long carefully portrayed himself as both a champion for racial equality and a reliable ally of law enforcement.

item.title: 'Outside Agitator' Claim Dates to Civil Rights Era
item.description: Amid widespread protests over police brutality after the death of George Floyd, some federal and local officials have blamed outsiders for stoking violence. Similar claims were made during the civil rights movement.
item.dc:creator: Jacey Fortin
item.media:credit: Associated Press
item.media:description: Civil rights demonstrators carried flags as they marched from Selma to Montgomery, Ala., in March 1965. At the time, officials warned that the movement was driven by “agitators” and “outsiders.”

item.title: The Palestinian Plan to Stop Annexation: Remind Israel What Occupation Means
item.description: Officials in the West Bank say they are willing to let the Palestinian Authority collapse if Israel applies its sovereignty over occupied territory.
item.dc:creator: David M. Halbfinger and Adam Rasgon
item.media:credit: Oded Balilty/Associated Press
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu plans to annex Israeli settlement on the West Bank, like Maale Michmash, above. The Palestinians are trying to pressure Israel by forcing it to resume many of the burdens of an occupying power.

item.title: Evelyn Caro, Nurse Who Realized a Lifelong Dream, Dies at 69
item.description: Nearing 50, with her children grown, she went back to school and became a nurse. She came out of retirement only to die of the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Steven Kurutz

item.title: Bail Is at Least $1 Million for Derek Chauvin, Ex-Officer Accused of Killing George Floyd
item.description: Derek Chauvin is charged with second-degree murder and second-degree manslaughter in Mr. Floyd’s death.
item.dc:creator: Kim Barker and Matt Furber
item.media:credit: Hennepin County Jail, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer charged with murder, in a mugshot provided by the Hennepin County Jail

item.title: Someone Found a Buried Treasure Hidden in the Rocky Mountains
item.description: Forrest Fenn, a New Mexico art collector, created a treasure hunt in 2010. Over the weekend, he said, someone found the chest he had buried with gold nuggets, coins, gems and artifacts.
item.dc:creator: Johnny Diaz
item.media:credit: Nick Cote for The New York Times
item.media:description: Forrest Fenn in 2016 at his home in Santa Fe, N.M. He has not revealed where he buried gold, gems and artifacts estimated to be worth $2 million.

item.title: Protests in L.A.: Garcetti's Proposal to Defund Police
item.description: Monday: Marqueece Harris-Dawson, a Los Angeles councilman, talks about why protests haven’t died down.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan
item.media:credit: Marcio Jose Sanchez/Associated Press
item.media:description: Demonstrators marched on Sunday in Hollywood, during a protest over the death of George Floyd.

item.title: Protesters, Everywhere (Including … Mitt Romney?)
item.description: Huge demonstrations and a rethinking of the Minneapolis police: This is your morning tip sheet.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello

item.title: When the Police Lie
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Jamie Quinn, via Reuters
item.media:description: Martin Gugino, a 75-year-old protester, lays on the ground after he was shoved by two police officers in Buffalo, New York.

item.title: Live Coronavirus Updates: New York Reopens
item.description: New York City tentatively starts to reopen, 100 days after its first case. U.S. air travel is picking up, fueled by vacationers.
item.media:credit: Sarah Blesener for The New York Times
item.media:description: Patrick Kearns of Leo F. Kearns Funeral Home at the entrance of a makeshift morgue in Brooklyn.

item.title: Shearing Sheep, and Hewing to Tradition, on an Island in Maine
item.description: In a remote area of Maine, the Wakeman family maintains the traditions of island shepherding, the cycles of which have been largely unchanged for centuries.
item.dc:creator: Greta Rybus and Galen Koch and Greta Rybus
item.media:credit: Greta Rybus
item.media:description: Evie Wakeman cares for a lamb named Pinney. Lambs may be brought in for additional care if their mother rejects them or isn’t able to feed them. A lamb that needs additional care will be bottle fed, warmed, and reintroduced to its mother. If reintroduction isn’t successful, the lamb will become a “dooryard sheep” at the Wakeman household.

item.title: As Las Vegas Reopens, a Huge Coronavirus Test for Casinos
item.description: While the contact-tracing challenges faced by Las Vegas are extreme, they highlight larger systemic problems in monitoring the coronavirus across the country.
item.dc:creator: Jo Becker
item.media:credit: John Locher/Associated Press
item.media:description: People playing craps at a table with transparent partitions after the reopening of the Bellagio Hotel & Casino on Thursday in Las Vegas.

item.title: Live Updates and Video on George Floyd Protests
item.description: Mourners are gathering to view George Floyd in Houston, the officer who knelt on his neck appeared in court, and calls for radical changes to policing are gaining steam.
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker/The New York Times

item.title: Live Stock Market News During the Coronavirus Pandemic
item.description: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.

item.title: A Nursing Home’s 64-Day Covid Siege: ‘They’re All Going to Die’
item.description: We tracked the outbreak, the struggle to contain it and the fallout, interviewing residents’ families and listening to their conference calls as they sought answers from the facility’s leaders.
item.dc:creator: Kim Barker
item.category: Burlington Health and Rehab Center (Burlington, Vt)
item.media:credit: Jacob Hannah for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Burlington Health & Rehab Center, where 39 residents tested positive for the virus.

item.title: Romney Marches With Protesters in Washington
item.description: The senator from Utah appeared to be the first Senate Republican to join the demonstrations over the killing of George Floyd, putting himself at odds with the president again.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane and Aishvarya Kavi
item.media:credit: Anna Moneymaker/The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Mitt Romney, Republican of Utah, had called George Floyd’s death “abhorrent.”

item.title: Minneapolis Will Disband Its Police Force, Council Members Pledge
item.description: Saying the existing Police Department cannot be reformed, a majority of the City Council has promised to rethink public safety from the ground up in the wake of George Floyd’s killing.
item.dc:creator: Dionne Searcey and John Eligon
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Angry protesters shouted at Mayor Jacob Frey in Minneapolis on Saturday.

item.title: Other Protests Flare and Fade. Why This Movement Already Seems Different.
item.description: The massive gatherings for racial justice across the country and now the world have achieved a scale and level of momentum not seen in decades.
item.dc:creator: Jack Healy and Kim Barker
item.media:credit: Alyssa Schukar for The New York Times
item.media:description: People gather Tuesday at the memorial where George Floyd died in the custody of the Minneapolis police.
